Spotlight Will Ferrell From SNL to the big screen "Land of the Lost" for instance is a monumentally stupid movie -- in fact calling it a movie at all is somewhat misleading; its mostly an extended skit that allows Will Ferrell and Danny McBride to bounce comedic riffs off one another using the occasional bit of dinosaur waste product for props. Director Brad Silberling never finds the right tone; many of the bits are far too adult for children yet no adult with a brain bigger than a walnut -- inside joke the filmmakers evidently thought was hilarious -- would find the story the least bit compelling. But theres this Its almost certainly not as awful as youd think. Of course youd think that a movie starring Ferrell based on the Sid and Marty Krofft show about time travel from the 70s would be awful indeed. That there are any laughs at all is something of a victory. Ferrell plays Dr. Rick Marshall a paleontologist who thinks hes discovered time warps that take you to places where "past present and future merge." Matt Lauer hosting him on the "Today" show isnt so sure. A smack-down follows Marshall is humiliated and the next thing we know hes teaching uninspired kids science. (Sample question If you sent a big bag of dope to the sun would it catch on fire and get everyone high?) Suddenly a fan shows up in the form of Holly (Anna Friel) who thinks his theories are anything but crackpot and wants to help him prove their veracity. Yes Holly was Marshalls daughter in the TV series but if youre looking for continuity here youre looking in the wrong place. For instance on the show Will was Marshalls son. Here hes a redneck huckster played by McBride with whom Marshall and Holly travel to an alternate world courtesy of the contraption Marshalls invented. There they encounter dinosaurs including a particularly nasty Tyrannosaurus rex named Grumpy a primate named Chaka (Jorma Taccone) and of course the Sleestaks. The story such as it is involves Enik (John Boylan) a Sleestak scientist convincing the trio they need to find Marshalls machine which was lost to save the universe. Thus they embark with Chaka on a journey to find it. This leads to a sort of desert dumping ground for missing planes ships and other vessels. It also affords Ferrell and McBride plenty of opportunity to hurl digs at one another. Ferrells performance is uneven though thats partly because playing Marshall as an egotistical boob limits him. Friel doesnt have a lot to do other than gamely allow Chaka to grab her chest repeatedly. Its McBride whos the most consistently funny. Whether its here "Pineapple Express" "The Foot Fist Way" or his HBO series "Eastbound amp; Down" McBride plays essentially the same character a foul-mouthed cretin with the possibility of a good heart (here more than ever). Its not lowbrow. Its no-brow. And its really funny. Good thing because without McBride "Land of the Lost" would be truly lost indeed. Check out the best travel deals and destinations Movies Entertainment Movies Movie Review Land of the Lost -- 2 out of 5 stars Danny McBride Will Ferrell and Anna Friel Universal Related "Land of the Lost" review "Land of the Lost" times and tickets "Land of the Lost" trailer Related "Land of the Lost" review "Land of the Lost" times and tickets "Land of the Lost" trailer (Universal) Roger MooreSentinel Staff Writer Stupid on an epic scale or epic on a stupid one Land of the Lost is as close as Will Ferrell comes these days to a "kid friendly" movie.A mildly ribald farce built around the 1970s childrens TV show about humans stuck in a parallel universe and the weird critters they find there Land of the Lost has been re-engineered for the Ron Burgundy Fan Club. And from the looks of things no expense was spared in hurling the worlds most infamous (and infamously lumpy) underwear model into a Journey to the Center of the Earth comic adventure. Ferrell plays Dr. Rick Marshall a crackpot scientist exiled to a minor museum after a meltdown during a Today Show interview with Matt Lauer.But shapely Brit grad student Holly (Anna Friel) hunts him down and convinces him that hes not mad that there are parallel universes and she has the fossilized cigarette lighter to prove it. Holly and the junk food addict Rick take his "tachyon amplifier" to a cheesy cave tourist attraction run by Will (Danny McBride) where an ordinary raft ride turns into a trip to "a cosmic lost and found" where pterodactyls fly past Fotomats Cessnas lie entangled with Viking longships and primitive ape-like creatures whose language Holly speaks dodge dinosaurs and get buzzed on fruit juice. Ricks theory -- that you can "travel sideways in time" to a "Land of the Lost" where "past present and future meet" --- is proven true. If only the daft scientist can find a way to get back to our time back on the Today Show. That Matt Lauer is in for it.As with most of Ferrells movies the wackiness spins out of riffs where the players (McBride is good at this) try to top each other with outrageous comments or exclamations."Captain Kirks nipples" "Sweet Gregor Mendel"A friendly apeman (Jorma Taccone) cops a feel. Rick shoves his hand down his shorts and Rick and Will react to a vibrating portal to other dimensions by using it to duet on Chers synthesized hit "Do You Believe in Life After Love?" Director Brad Silberlings best picture was Lemony Snicket but hes content to keep the effects convincing and make sure Ferrells reactions to a "grumpy" T-rex are in sync with them. Other than that just let the stars do their faintly off-color romping and riffing through a chunk of the desert Southwest where they dont mind if you stick a movie set there and have to listen to a lot of Will Ferrell screaming.Parents who fondly recall the 70s TV show may be a bit surprised at the tenor of this sometimes hilarious but stupid and slapdash star vehicle. But thats what the kids are laughing at these days -- "Thats gay" jokes masturbation gags pot references and dino doo-doo.But even if nobody sells a dino-poo gag like Ferrell thats nothing to take to the bank or the Today Show is it?
